This happened before the living will law was passed in PA. In choosing Judith Dunning's story to open this article, Paula Span shows that she understands--though her readers still may not-- the well-documented fact that it is fear of disability, not fear of pain, which drives people to this step. Even Compassion & Choices admits, in the words of the head of their New York office, that "Pain is not the issue." This is because of the availability of palliative and terminal sedation, well-covered elsewhere in the NYT recently.
What led Ms. Dunning to end her life was fear of disability. As another commenter has posted, all disability-rights organizations to take a position oppose these laws.
"More centrally, Ms. Dunning . . . was losing her ability to speak. . . .
'She felt she had completed all the important tasks of her life,' recalled her physician, Dr. Michael Rabow, director of the symptom management service at the University of California, San Francisco. 'When she could no longer communicate [via speech], life was no longer worth living.'"
Dr. Rabow's choice of words illustrates why so many disability-rights activists are very concerned that our lives, so often thought by able-bodied people to be "no longer worth living," are put at great risk by these laws.

This doesn't address the issue of your implicit devaluation of disabled human beings, their feelings, and their lives. If "aid in dying" was a truly compassionate organization, it would advocate for the availability of barbiturates for ALL people, instead of implying that seniors and the disabled are less than human and therefore don't deserve health care.

What makes a life worth living (or not) depends greatly on the individual.  A lot depends on which abilities the person views as central to their identity; in this case, speech was the capacity she couldn't live without.  Another person might be ok with not speaking if they could text, but something else might be crucial to their enjoyment of life.  Aid in dying movements are not euthanasia movements putting people involuntarily to death, they are offering choices to those who wish to make them.  If there is any ethical question here related to disability, it is related to whether disabled persons are able to access sufficient supports to remain independent (whether or not they are terminally ill).  That is where the fight should be.

As Brittany Maynard eloquently expressed, pain is not the only issue. It can also be unendurable to decline slowly and become weaker and weaker, to have repeated convulsions, to have difficulty breathing, and many other terrible ills of dying. The arrogance of those who only want to count pain as a problem that could justify doing something to hasten an inevitable death is to me great.

Anne, Dr. Rabow was referring to Ms. Dunning's feelings about what made life worth living, not his own.
Years of data from Oregon and Washington do indeed show that pain is not the primary reason people choose to legally hasten their deaths. It's not even Reason #2 or #3. They are driven by the "decreased ability to participate in the activities that make life enjoyable," and by loss of autonomy and dignity. This information is made public annually; it's no secret.

The dossier provides material that can be taken as data for a set of conjectures (in this case, hypotheses that cannot easily be tested by the press), provided by someone whose credentials were verified (by David Korn; see his article in Mother Jones), even if the content could not.  Investigation is very much in the public interest, but the press is unlikely to be capable of doing that investigation.  Do they then have the right to keep that material from public view?  Or do they have an obligation to publish to enable someone else to investigate?  I think the latter.

Deb—I dispute the third sentence of your comment on 1A. In my junior year of college I took an elective Shakespeare course for non-English majors. We studied ten of the most popular plays in ten weeks—my first intensive exposure to the Bard. For years afterward I was instantly able to ID *any* snippet of dialogue from any of these plays—speaker, situation, location in the script—almost instinctively. I always knew that being able to do that wasn't due to any brilliance on my part but was solely a result of the perfection of Shakespeare's poetry, scripting, and construction. More than half a century later, coming up with ACT II was a breeze for me. I'm sure a lot of other solvers had a similar experience.

Also, Deb, a quibble, though with the dictionaries not you. To say that YAW "means to move back and forth along a flight path" is faulty in several ways. First, "back and forth," without some indicator of the direction of such movement, could as easily mean backward and forward, instead of side to side, its actual meaning. Second, YAWing is not limited to flight; a boat can also yaw in, and probably under, water. Also, planes landing in a stiff lateral wind may deliberately yaw after touching down to maintain a straight course on the runway.

I agree that the dictionary definition of yaw is misleading when it states that it entails a back and forth movement or, in some definitions, an oscillation. The crossword clue, as usual, I feel was accurate and fair. Yawing may entail a regular or reciprocal variation around central point, but it doesn’t have to. It’s simply a deviation or movement about the defined vertical axis of an object. This is frequently thought of as "left or right" (hence "side to side" incorrectly implying ocillation), not usually back and forth.

The yaw axis is perpendicular to the wings on an airplane (or the deck of a boat). The amount of yaw is the amount rotation of the nose of the object around this axis. A boat will yaw into a cross current (also known as “crabbing”) to maintain a heading. An airplane will crab into the wind to maintain a heading as well. Based on the strength and direction of the wind, the nose of the aircraft will be at some angle off the intended heading while the path over the ground will be - if done correctly - the desired heading. Since wind that happens to be blowing at any given time may not be aligned with runway, aircraft have to crab into the wind on final to stay aligned with the runway centerline; pilots reduce yaw to zero upon touchdown since the friction of the tires resists any yawing force from the wind. If bored sometime, try searching “cross wind landings” on Youtube. Seeing the amount of crab required in high cross wind landings can be exciting.
Perhaps this thread needs a YAW damper?

One of the most memorable landings in my life was coming down under high cross winds to land at the old airport in Hong Kong - the one where you were flying straight into a mountain popping up out of the sea. Wild. Ride.

Thankfully, very experienced pilots.

VIOLENT felons [whether pardoned or having completed their sentences] should be PERMANENTLY barred from owning guns.
[I exclude the cases where the pardon was because new evidence showed the person was wrongly convicted.]
The Times article cited below describes cases where violent felons [including felons convicted of murder] legally obtained new guns and then used those guns to commit new crimes including murder.
Whether felons should be allowed to vote is an entirely separate issue.
The question of gun ownership and voting rights are entirely different.

http://www.nytimes.com/2011/11/14/us/felons-finding-it-easy-to-regain-gu...

"Under federal law, people with felony convictions forfeit their right to bear arms. Yet every year, thousands of felons across the country have those rights reinstated, often with little or no review. In several states, they include people convicted of violent crimes, including first-degree murder and manslaughter, an examination by The New York Times has found.
While previously a small number of felons were able to reclaim their gun rights, the process became commonplace in many states in the late 1980s, after Congress started allowing state laws to dictate these reinstatements — part of an overhaul of federal gun laws orchestrated by the National Rifle Association"

Needless to say Manning and Snowden would make waves. But there are thousands whose lives you could make better. These people are precious like every person is. Of course, there are unscrupulous schools interested mainly in making a buck regardless of the mayhem they cause. But another serious issue is that even for some who complete their training there is no work, or work only under very limiting conditions. The simple fact is that the modern economy cannot make use of them.

Of course, we know of the history behind many modern successes that began when talented people had to leave large corporations and start their own because their employers lacked the imagination to capitalize on their work. A lack of corporate imagination and the lengths to which large companies will go to stifle new ideas and kill competition is a trite tail today.

But the problem is actually bigger than the failure to see new opportunities to make money. It is the failure to see the corporation as a citizen capable of more than improving its own bottom line - capable of contributing far more than widgets and advertising and aristocrats, capable of enabling people to do creative and socially important work. Work, by the way, that absolutely must be done, even if it does not make the very comfortable even more comfortable.

It is not true that independent state boards do a good job determining clemency. They have been shown to be affected by how close to meals appeals come before them. They suffer from availability bias in that, after a report of a parolee committing a crime, they refuse any clemency decisions for years.

I agree that President Obama should use the pardon power more often.  It is not the fault of the pardoned person that her selection appears to have been the result of a lottery.  Your suggestions about the office of the president using the power more objectively and transparently as many states do is excellent.  But your description of the pardon power as applying only to convicted persons who have served their sentences is completely incorrect.  Please recall that President Ford pardoned Richard Nixon before he had ever been charged with a crime.  While I am sure that there are many persons deserving of a pardon, one person should clearly receive one, Hillary Clinton.  She has been through enough.

I know, I know, for what you ask? Numerous, cocksure reasons rolled off his tongue for the necessity of a pardon, as though when not wiring large houses for very wealthy people he's an understudy fill-in for Alex Jones.

He's a good man for the most part, though I hate his pandering to the wealthy politics. We are opposites but respect each other at work. It is useful having a super hard core right wing insider to interact with, so that the "weird thought magic" going on in that side of America can be understood in the context of a person with a face whom you get along with at work.
You haven't seen abysmally low yet. Wait until Trump gets into office.
Bill Clinton pardoned fugitive Marc Rich, so maybe there another deep pocket contributor out there who should also be pardoned.
I have a hard time imagining that pardons will be anywhere on Trumps agenda... except for the few white-collar criminals. who are white.

I agreed with every point made here, except the last sentence, which is gratuitously aggressive and patently impossible.  Yes, Obama's pardon record is abysmal.  Do the editors really believe his successor will learn from Obama or even has the compassion to consider more pardons?

President Obama, for all the weight he has carried on his shoulders alone, has been willing to use clemency, especially for non-violent drug offenders. He has spoken very convincingly about the injustice of disproportionate sentences for minor crimes.
President Obama is, however, but one person and has just days left in office. He alone cannot right the wrongs of our criminal justice system. This will take a concerted effort to reach Congress and Governors to rewrite legislation keeping more people from being incarcerated in a lopsided manner for respective offenses. Even the Koch brothers have expressed support for rewriting the laws.
Seeing the forest for the trees means looking far beyond President Obama's last days.
